comments.commentBody:
Unbelievable.

I'm beginning to truly think that Susan Anderson is a double agent. What else could possibly explain such incoherent flaws in logic?

She states in the same sentence:

"...real skeptics question all sides...I'm not willing to check CA"

This debate keeps getting stranger every minute.
Bob:  The "non-robust result" is only in the context of the paper we are discussing.  The hockey stick is extremely robust, having been replicated a dozen times by a dozen other groups.

Tom Scharf-

"I'm beginning to truly think that Susan Anderson is a double agent. What else could possibly explain such incoherent flaws in logic?"

That's funny!
I had the same thought about Roddy several months ago after reading one of his particularly invidious (thanks for the great word, Andy!) comments. I have been recommending Roddy's comments ever since, regardless of content. I guess I should do the same for Susan now...

What's really weird is that phony skeptics are now trying to shred the present by using the past, and trying to use a scientific publication they wish to discredit to provide credit for their views.

I've gone back and read RealClimate and the Marcott paper, FAQ, and press release in full. I find that the comments here are not justified by the material.

Given the nature of scientific inquiry, which was my opening comment before all these personal attacks came in, it would always have been predictable that this extension of the climate record would bring in the big guns to alter the meaning of the original material.

Some of you are right, however, an observant layperson like me will be disadvantaged in the face of such an organized attack, and my honesty and worries which usually serve me well were ill-suited to such a swarm. The RealClimate people did much better, sticking to a standard of courtesy, absence of personal attack, and real science throughout.

"Best practice" is always a moving target. By-and-large, I agree with evidence-based health care as a key approach to improving the quality and cost-effectiveness of care, and ultimately improving the health of patients and the population. But evidence-based health care has two downsides we must be vigilant in preventing or at least limiting:

- Difficulties of those who regulate practices (or payment for practices) keeping on top of the evidence of just what is best practice, as in the case described in this article;

- Too high a bar for allowable "evidence" which can stifle innovation & keep practices with demonstrated success--but not strongly enough demonstrated--from being used or paid for. This is relative. For drugs, a "gold standard" of experimental & control studies is always (or almost always) correct. For many other medical practices the bar should probably also be high, but might vary, for example, if it will take too long or economically infeasible to do controlled studies. As practices move more to the social side of health, e,g., nurse assistance for poor mothers with infants or helping people maintain healthy behaviors, the bar should be lower to enable promising practices (again, with SOME demonstrated success) to be used, funded, and benefit more people sooner. The noted social scientist Lisbeth Schorr has referred to this as "evidence-informed" practice, which she thinks is often a more appropriate standard than "evidence-based" practice.

The theory of Mellon appears to include drastic price cutting to be "complete" in terms of economic depressions. Yet the government, then and now, are moving heaven and earth to support current prices and even push them higher. The Mellon-ites along with Friedman-ites say they want the free market to determine prices but only if prices will increase. Remember the wailing as home prices fell? The current depression tried to do its "job" and lower prices as the Mellon-ites want. That the most recent depression failed to correct prices is due to the fact that the free marketeers obstruct the markets and manipulate the markets for their own gains. Then again free marketeers did the same thing in the 1930s. The difference, back then we had a government and electorate that saw through their lies and obstruction.
It's as stupid as allowing one's superstitions to supersede logic, fact and experience.
Thanks, Leapy.  A shame I couldn't follow up that triumph in the rest of the puzzle.

LL, With that "You are one smart COKIE" reply to suejean, it appears that once again you've gone and Doone it!

Girl! When RU gonna Lorna?

BOQ

Sweet little sandwich you put together there, HML.

Merci BOQ you.

This was a real nice puzzle - about average Friday difficulty with lots of nice entries and crunchy clues, but I found OKIES and DEIST a little unfair.

The South side came together surprisingly easily starting in the SW corner, after which the rest of the bottom half fell like a matchstick castle. The first word that popped into my mind when I saw "____ Island" was Rikers, but it didn't fit.

EL CAPITAN gave me the NE quite easy, but the NW with all those unexpected K-words gave me some trouble. I loved the WEE LAD and the EXACTA clues best, but that "relatively important meeting" takes the cake.

I so wanted GOOD CHOCOLATE for 31A. Alas, it wasn't to be.

I hope everyone has Mr. Bluebird on their shoulder, and it all will be satisfactual this Friday.

It's not psychology -- it's economics! You and Dr. K. are being rather naive, each in your own way.

Remember -- if they say it's not about the money -- it's about the money!

I could care less about Russians. My complaint is actually on US wealthy and corporate who have by buying congre$$ been able to create these neat little tax havens. And yes to the extent that the worldwide wealthy screw their countrymen then I would say that while legal it is immoral. If they can keep theirs then where do I shelter mine. The answer from the IRS will be pay.

We once adopted a Great Pyrenees whose name was Avalanche. While driving her to her new home in a ski resort, we realized that calling out, "Avalanche"  up on the hill might cause a sensation. She got a new name.

The problem with slow turn-around is adjuncts, graduate students and lecturers are burdened with only teaching composition courses, and so are responding to literally hundreds of essays every few weeks. A genuine essay takes about 15 minutes to respond to. Some take more. Some less. Multiply that by 125 (the number of students I have this semester). That's roughly 31-ish hours. Every paper cycle. That's just GRADING one batch of essays. Forget all the other work. Yes, slow feedback happens all the time, which is why I for one would welcome this software if - as I've said above - the software wasn't the last word on a grade. If I could grade writing that had been carefully drafted and seriously revised, Those 31 ish hours could be greatly reduced.

Slow feedback? Learn patience. Leaving things to sit ruminate and pickle for a while is a good thing in writing.  Everyone is in love with the darlings they just wrote....but get it back three weeks later and you just might see the holes and errors in thinking you made.   Getting some distance gives perspective.

I wouldn't recommend this software for final grades, but there is a big problem where teachers seem to think it is acceptable to wait 3-4 weeks to give someone feedback on their writing. Maybe no one else has had teachers like that, but it does happen. This would be great for students learning to write basic essays - ones that do follow a set script. They could get feedback relatively quickly and learn to make changes when what they did was fresh. Feedback that could be incorporated into the assignments that occur over the next month instead of continuing to make the same mistakes because the teachers were not able to provide them the necessary feedback in an appropriate timeframe.

It is entirely possible for computer software "to read" and evaluate a paper. There may even be a role for it in immediate responses to essays written as practices or in concert with human scoring. What the electronic evaluation and response cannot do is substitute for teachers reading and evaluating their students' work and in the process acquiring direct knowledge of their students' abilities, interests, and personalities. Some respondents have written that the electronic evaluation is necessary for large classes. In truth the large classes that "seem" to require these devices are not necessary. Real education involves teachers, professors if you wish,  working closely with students to accomplish competence in the discipline being studied and in the growth of students as persons. Lest we forget, the dynamics involved also contribute to the intellectual and social well being of the teachers.

Mr. Krugman, you are so right! But you miss an essential point. In the eyes of those who control the private sector, it is more profitable for them to clean up the mess (a mess that they made) than it is for the government to do so. You don't have to be an economist to see that having government do the job of righting the economy (unless under the guise of military spending) means more regulation, less freedom, and less profit.

Private health care is less efficient, but far more profitable for those who run it. Private infrastructure projects are diverse and messy creating opportunities for profit. Huge differences in income and unemployment breed more ways to make a quick buck. This is the fundamental difference between what you call Mellonites and Keynesian economics.

Your approach favors the citizens who suffer from economic disasters. Their approach seems like (and is) purging. They view the economy as a resource, not as a collection of human beings trying to get by. Their attitude towards the economy is the same as those who view our planet - as a vast self-healing wilderness to be mined and felled for profit.

You can argue all the facts and figures all you want, but they won't listen. They must be harnessed and regulated. They will only respond to force - the language they live by. They have a different agenda than you, and learned this reality long ago. They mock your arguments as a sign of weakness. I know they are a sign that you're one of the good guys.

I had a Basset Hound that I lost a year ago today. Her name was Hyacinth - as in Hyacinth Bucket from Keeping Up Appearancees. She was much like her name sake - completely self abosrobed, and she made everyone laugh with her antics.
Her name does not follow the formula - but it suited her to a T and I miss her.

I now have a dog named Miles - because he was a rescue who traveled a long way to get to the city where I live - he came from Kentucky and landed in Minneapolis. The truck he was riding in broke down on the highway and the poor dogs had to be handled on the side of a highway to get to another vehicle. He has come MILES in his very short life..

The other dog is named Enzo - for the dog in the book, the Art of Racing in the Rain. I think there are a lot of dogs that were named Enzo shortly after the book came out. I ran into one at the groomer the last time Enzo got trimmed - that dog's owner was a bit perturbed that her dog's name was not unique - perhaps she thought she was the only one who read the book. It was funny - the groomers had to vie for which Enzo they would groom. When I got him at the shelter, they said he was part Bolognese - so I figured he needed an Italian name.

I also have a cat named Joe Torre - he is awesome ... and so is his namesake.

When I first saw my 6-week old black Lab, female, I held her in my arms and she looked like a beutiful little lady.  The only name that came immediately to mind was Lily.  She looked so sweet and happy and she still is, so Lily it is -- except when she desroyed my eyeglasses, ran around the backyard with a piece of laundered clothing or ate a chicken sandwich - I called her, under my breath, Devil Dog. She no longer does   those things and still looks like a beautiful Lily!

I have always thought you should name a dog with a name that makes you smile every time you say it.  We are a foster family for Lab Rescue, and because so many dogs come through our organization, we have an alphabetical rotation like the weather service uses for hurricanes each year.  It keeps things straight at the vet and on our website, but clearly most of those dogs need to be renamed as soon as they are adopted by their forever families.  I am amused when some families are reluctant to change their names for fear of confusing them.  The dogs are typically adopted in just ten days to two weeks, and we usually have no idea what names they used in their past.  Pick a name you like to say, that makes you smile, and gets you a wagging tail.  That is the best one that works!
I disagree. Vicki Hearne's abusive "training" methods are, to put it mildly, outdated.

We had one family "rule" for naming our dogs. The name had to match the origin of the breed. Hence, our German Short Haired Pointer was Gunner; our Irish Setter was Finian Kelly (called Kelly); our English Springer Spaniel was Vicar.  I've kept the tradition intact. My English Setter was Willoughby, and now my toy poodle is Hugo Louis de Gaulle, aka Hugo. Of course this rule does not apply to mixed breeds: our rescue was named Mary Rose.
Amazing.  Eight years ago I was looking for a Havanese because of allergies, also.  I couldn't find a breeder near where I live, so instead got a cockapoo, who I named Chico, also.
My mother did that even though our dogs' names were Happy and Checkers.  I think I would have preferred Heidi.
I happen to be Harbingers human Grand Aunt, and he is a lovely and sweet dog, with a wonderful name.

Blitz was my significant other's magnificent, even as a puppy, White German Shepherd Dog who nearly was named Ritz until I intervened. There is nothing like a German Shepherd.

I had Flash for weeks before I was inspired by the zigzag mark under his neck that reminded me of the insignia on the uniform of the comic book The Flash. And, it was perfect for his personality. I've loved all my dogs, but was gaga over Flash.

I had not had a dog for 25 years and didn't know dew claws when I saw them and named Polly for polydactylism.

I named my first dog, who I got in kindergarten and who lived until I was a sophomore in college, Pinky for the big time kiddy TV star of the day Pinky Lee,

My other four were inherited and were named by others: Shadow, Astro, Cosmo and Tippy. All gone now except 16 year old Tippy.
That's a neat idea, I may have to name my next dog Wafi after come here in Fon spoken in Benin.

Adopted an older, male Lab who'd been picked up as a stray. Tried every obvious Lab name, and lots of not-so-obvious. No luck, no response.

One day discovered he responded to -- "Baby". So that was it.

Don't think this was his official name, but it was comforting to learn that somewhere, sometime in his past, someone had loved him enough to call him Baby - a lot.
Perfect!  I can see it in my mind's eye.

My husband and I were reading Goethe's Faust when we got our first cats, so we were thinking Faust and Mephistopheles.  When we heard that Mephistopheles had been called "Nicky" before, that sealed it, because it's another name for the devil.  Of course, we never called him by all 5 syllables - we shortened it to "Pheles", aka "fleas".  But sitting in the vet's office with 2 identical cat carriers when they called our last name, I asked my husband, "Do you have Pheles?" and he said, "Yup".  Everyone moved away just a bit!  They were both wonderful cats, and we still miss them!

Love your article!  My 15 year -old white miniature poodle is gorgeous both inside and out. Never shown, but a certified therapy dog who always bring a smile to everyone, he is truly a gift and my absolute best best friend.  From day one we have never used his champion name - he is Tov Meod (loosely translated from the Hebrew for Very Good, Goodness) and he is the essence of that. He knows he is Tov and I cherish every day with him.
